content.title: Brown Beach House, live from the seafront

introduction.small: This trendy hotel offers a stunning view of the beach, and proves to be a perfect location to discover Tel Aviv by foot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brown Beach House, live from the seafront

paragraphs.text:
A mere promenade separates Brown Beach House from Jerusalem Beach. In Tel Aviv, this recent boutique hotel offers heavenly views of the seafront or the city from the 49 bedrooms. They all provide a private terrace and unveil different charms. Brown Beach House's contemporary decoration also shows a few retro touches, like a tribute to the 1950s with this neon sign on the front of the building that represents a pink flamingo, black and white striped flooring and singular light fixtures on the ceiling.
The whole family will be delighted as various points of interest are located less than 15 minutes away from the hotel by foot. When the sun is shining, put on your bathing suit and dive in the nearby Mediterranean Sea, or into the spa's Jacuzzi. The latter is situated on the panoramic terrace, from which you can enjoy gorgeous views in a very relaxing manner.

Brown Beach House
HaYarkon St 64
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 7605000

www.brownhotels.com/beach/

Rooms: from 550 ILS

content.title: Discover contemporary Israeli cuisine at Ha'achim

introduction.small: In Tel Aviv, Ha'achim's spirit can be summed up as family, no frills gastronomy, best enjoyed in an inviting atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover contemporary Israeli cuisine at Ha'achim

paragraphs.text:
Dine like a true local and explore Israeli flavours at Ha'achim's. Located on the large Ibn Gabriol, the restaurant is a meeting ground for hipsters, with exposed stone walls, post-industrial style and various herbs covering the counter. Besides its trendy decoration, the establishment takes the stance of a family affair – Ha'achim means “brothers” in Hebrew. Regulars come to share a few mezze based off traditional recipes, but revisited with more contemporary touch, as well as fresh and local ingredients. Fried artichokes, labneh, hummus, shakshuka (poached eggs, tomatoes and feta cheese) or some challah, the famous braided brioche baked for Sabbat… Friday and Saturday, the restaurant is also opened for brunch. Tables are quickly taken by families and groups of friends, so remember to book in advance!

Ha'achim
Shlomo Ibn Gabirol St 12
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 6917171

www.haachim.co.il

Menu: around 70 ILS

content.title: Cocktail passion at Double Standard

introduction.small: In Tel Aviv's old northern neighbourhood, Double Standard offers cocktails that brim with originality and inventiveness.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cocktail passion at Double Standard

paragraphs.text:
Tables are covered with funny-looking glasses at Double Standard. In Tel Aviv, this bar specialised in cocktail-making stands out with its use of special crockery in the first place. It is therefore possible to sip on a cocktail in a mini Easter Island statue, an English teacup, the head of a Roman emperor, a shark's or a delicate swan. As for the Bloody Mary, it is served in what looks like a… blood bag! Which should please the city's trendy youth, gathering during happy hours and looking for more innovation and originality.
More than an unusual universe, Double Standard is first and foremost a bar where cocktails – to be enjoyed in moderation – are being prepared like fine dishes, with fruits, vegetables, condiments and various spices, like The Charmer, topped with red peppers and garlic. What a thrill!

Double Standard
Dizengoff St 247
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 9668498

www.facebook.com/dsbarshop/ 

Menu: 46 ILS for a signature cocktail

content.title: Bana, an ode to plant-based gastronomy

introduction.small: In Tel Aviv's Lev Hair district, the Bana vegan restaurant highlights plants' fundamental flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bana, an ode to plant-based gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
For some time now, Tel Aviv's gastronomic scene has veered vegan… and Bana is on the forefront of the movement. The restaurant reminds us of 1980s California, with a pared-down design, white tones and pastel pinks. It presents a menu that sheds a light on fruits and vegetables, as Bana's goal is to focus on plants' essential flavours. Fully vegan, the menu changes with the seasons. You may be a fervent vegan or simply curious to try something new, but the zucchini quiche with cashew nuts and cherry tomatoes will make everyone see eye to eye. Same goes for sweet potatoes, stuffed with black lentils and a pistachio pesto, or the mushroom butternut with nut cream and topped with grilled hazelnuts. A simple yet original manner of finding what food really tastes like!

Bana
Nahmani St 36
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 6991566

www.facebook.com/BANACHMANI/

Menu: around 80 ILS

content.title: At Shila, the deft hand of Sharon Cohen

introduction.small: Two blocks from the Mediterranean Sea, Shila has become Tel Aviv's must-try restaurant within just a few years.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At Shila, the deft hand of Sharon Cohen

paragraphs.text:
In a modern dining room, you will be impatiently waiting for your dish to arrive. The menu is so tempting that it is difficult to choose. Chef Sharon Cohen brings together flavours to perfection to offer you dishes as beautiful to look at as it is tantalising to the taste buds. On the menu, choose the red tuna carpaccio as a starter, with wasabi, soy sauce and a dash of Campari – a great way to start off your meal! Then, indulge in a seafood lasagne or, for meat lovers, a risotto with duck breast.
To accompany your dishes, you will find your happiness on the particularly expansive wine list. You will find all types of designations, from Chablis to Fronsac and Gewurztraminer, from all countries: France, Italy, New Zealand, Israel and Argentina. Nonetheless, consume with moderation.

Shila – Sharon Cohen Kitchen & Bar
182 Ben Yehuda Street
Tel Aviv 61000

+972 (0)3 522 1224

en.shila-rest.co.il

Menu: from 200 ILS

content.title: The Norman Tel Aviv, an oasis of comfort

introduction.small: In the heart of the White City, The Norman unfolds all of its qualities, and they are many: luxurious rooms, a rooftop deck, wellness spa…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Norman Tel Aviv, an oasis of comfort

paragraphs.text:
In the very heart of Tel Aviv, The Norman Hotel invested in two buildings from the 1920s to transform them into luxury establishments. Challenge met, because you will love to bask in this bubble of comfort. As you enter the hall, you will be enveloped by the light. White tones predominate, and large windows allow a nurturing light to penetrate through. The same goes for each of the 50 rooms and suites. All unique – each decorated in a different style, they are very bright, and their contemporary design is accentuated by antique Renaissance-style elements.
The hotel's roof was designed to give you a sense a freedom: transparent railings allow for a limitless view of the city of Tel Aviv, while you enjoy a swim in the magnificent swimming pool and cool off in the sun. If you rather prefer salt water, know that the sea is only a 20-minute walk away. The Norman also has a spa, for even more relaxation, where you can unwind under the practitioners' expert hands.

The Norman Tel Aviv
23-25 Nachmani Street
Tel Aviv 6579441

+972 (0)3 543 5555

www.thenorman.com

Rooms: from 1,850 ILS

content.title: ‘Dizengoffing' on Dizengoff

introduction.small: Tel Aviv's first mayor, Meir Dizengoff gave his name to a street, a square, and a shopping centre, now a temple for shoppers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ‘Dizengoffing' on Dizengoff

paragraphs.text:
Lined with gnarled Ficus, Dizengoff Street is home to fashionable boutiques, trendy cafés, and restaurants to the south, towards the square of the same name. On Tuesdays and Fridays, it is crowded with stands selling handmade jewellery, vintage clothing, and accessories across from the stores, nestled in a flea market near the pedestrian bridge.

To the north, however, are the hairdressers and bridal shops that compete for space in a quiet residential area. Dizengoff Street has become a paradise for strollers. One no longer says ‘walk', but literally ‘dizengoff' in the popular parlance.

The Dizengoff Centre is the number one shopping centre in the city and will delight fashionistas with more than 420 shops, two cinemas, and even a gym with a swimming pool on the roof. It receives an average of 60,000 visitors a day!

Dizengoff Centre
Dizengoff St 50,
64332 Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 6212400

www.dizengof-center.co.il

content.title: Montefiore's many attractions

introduction.small: Opened only eight years ago, the first boutique hotel in Tel Aviv is also the most glamorous, thanks to its 1920s Bauhaus building. It also hosts a very good restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Montefiore's many attractions

paragraphs.text:
Located in a restored Bauhaus building, the Montefiore is an institution that is luxurious, distinguished, and simple. Renowned for its warmth, intimacy, and sense of refinement, this hotel offers a highly personalised service with twice daily housekeeping, an exceptional concierge service and fresh cookies at your bedside every night.

In its 12 rooms, expect libraries filled with books in English, furniture by Bauhaus pioneer Thonet, vanguard Israeli art, and large windows with spectacular views of the neighbourhood. Eight of these rooms also have a small private balcony. Sit out on the terrace, dine in the hotel's restaurant, one of the best addresses in the city, and end the evening in the excellent cocktail bar.

Just steps from the Rothschild Boulevard, the Montefiore places you at only a ten-minute walk from the beaches and main attractions of Tel Aviv.

Hotel Montefiore
36, Montefiore Street
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 5646100

www.hotelmontefiore.co.il

Rooms: from 1,420 ILS

content.title: Manta Ray: fine dining and a view of the sea

introduction.small: The Manta Ray combines fresh seafood and a fantastic location on the edge of the Mediterranean, right on the Alma Beach promenade.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Manta Ray: fine dining and a view of the sea

paragraphs.text:
Orchestrated by chef Ronen Skinezes, the Manta Ray is famous for its light and creative Middle Eastern food, with an emphasis on seafood. Perched at the southern end of the Tel Aviv promenade, the restaurant offers beautiful interiors and a terrace that is perfect for seeing and being seen during sunny days. It is equally good for relaxing and looking at the waves, which are so close.

Treat yourself to a dish of sautéed shrimp and freshly caught crab, accompanied by divine gnocchi with cream. Be tempted by the wide selection of mezze: eggplant salad, red mullet ceviche, or salmon tartare. Enjoy a grilled sea bream with rosemary and olive oil or a copious aubergine risotto, squid and Saint-Jacques.

Open from 9:00 a.m. to midnight, the Manta Ray is ideal for a casual lunch or a festive dinner with friends.

Manta Ray
Alma Beach,
7 Koifman St
Tel Aviv, 68012

+972 03 5174773

www.mantaray.co.il

Menu: around 130 ILS

content.title: The Charles Bronfman Auditorium : a musical palace

introduction.small: Formerly called the Palace of Culture, this venue still resonates with its legendary 1957 inaugural concert under the baton of Leonard Bernstein, with Arthur Rubinstein at the piano.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Charles Bronfman Auditorium : a musical palace

paragraphs.text:
The inaugural programme of the Palace of Culture in 1957 has entered legend through the fusional links between the conductor Leonard Bernstein, a native of Massachusetts and the composer of West Side Story, pianist Arthur Rubenstein as the featured performer, and the IPO, the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, which subsequently took up permanent residence there.

Another date remains famous for its surreal scene. On February 23, 1991, the violinist Isaac Stern played the ‘Partita No. 2 in D minor' for solo violin after the musicians left the stage because of an Iraqi Scud-missile warning; the audience donned gas masks and stayed.

Since its renovation in May 2013, resulting in improved acoustics (signed by Japanese acoustician Yasuhisa Toyota), the centre has changed its name in tribute to the great Canadian-American philanthropist Charles Bronfman. The first conductor to direct The Palestine Philharmonic Orchestra, the ancestor of the IPO, was Arturo Toscanini in 1936.

Charles Bronfman Auditorium
Huberman St 1
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 5430777

www.hatarbut.co.il

content.title: The sacred land of Bauhaus

introduction.small: Bauhaus flourished in the 1930s in Tel Aviv partially because of the presence of 17 former students of the Bauhaus School, who worked here as architects.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The sacred land of Bauhaus

paragraphs.text:
Fleeing the Nazis after they closed the Bauhaus School of Berlin in 1933, Jewish architects, followers of Walter Gropius, metamorphosed Tel Aviv into an experimental laboratory of modernist ideas. Among them were Erich Mendelsohn, Richard Kauffmann, Genia Averbuch, Arieh Sharon, Dov Carmi, Zeev Rechter, Pinchas Hueth,and Joseph Neufeld.

Not to mention Shlomo Gepstein, who designed the Shlomo Yafe home, the setting for the Bauhaus Museum on Bialik Street, in the historical district of Tel Aviv. Renovated in 1996,it is the place where many walking tours commence. Coming from various countries, they built an exceptional quarter together, using modern, minimalist architecture in accordance with Bauhaus precepts that place human beings at the centre of all requirements. Housing must be primarily functional and simple, and open to the exterior.

There are about 1,500 buildings still standing, including 200 masterpieces that motivated its inclusion as a World Heritage Site in 2003.

Bauhaus Centre Tel Aviv
77 Dizengoff St
Tel Aviv 6433249

+972 03 5220249

www.bauhaus-center.com

content.title: The Container: spirited cuisine

introduction.small: A resolutely trendy spot nestled in the Jaffa port district, which mixes up Middle Eastern and North African dishes to a DJ beat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Container: spirited cuisine

paragraphs.text:
At once bar, restaurant, and gallery, The Container is an all-in-one space overflowing with energy and enthusiasm. Ensconced in an old warehouse, the interiors have kept their industrial look with corrugated steel bar, brick walls, concrete floors, and bare fixtures.

Used as an art gallery, The Container exhibits paintings, posters, and wall hangings created by Israeli and international artists. The menu marries Middle Eastern and North African dishes, while putting the emphasis on seafood. Taste the Jerusalem artichokes with truffles and enoki mushrooms or gnocchi with ricotta, butter and sage.

Owner of the nearby deli, chef and jet setter Vince Muster adapts his menu daily. Dine outside, facing the fishing boats on the Mediterranean, before the DJs come on.

The Container
Jaffa Port, Warehouse 2
Tel Aviv 68129

+972 03 6836321

www.container.org.il

Menu: around 170 ILS

content.title: The DMH metamorphoses Holon

introduction.small: DMH the Design Museum Holon has become, in the image of the Guggenheim Bilbao, the icon of the city, transforming a bedroom community into a tourist destination through culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The DMH metamorphoses Holon

paragraphs.text:
Located about 30 minutes from Tel Aviv, the Design Museum Holon has been a delight for art lovers since it opened in 2010 on the occasion of the 60th anniversary of the city.

An architectural jewel in itself, the building, designed and conceived by one of the leading figures in international design, Ron Arad (born in Tel Aviv in 1951), seduces with its bold curves and red palette of five sinuous ribbons of Corten steel, imported from Bergamo (Italy), with their varying degrees of erosion. Inside, let yourself be carried away by original and thematic exhibitions that are biased towards the creators of the 21st century, such as Iris van Herpen.

Israel's first museum to be entirely devoted to design, the DMH enjoys a strong international reputation that has made this community into a prime stop on the Tel Aviv tourist trail.

DMH – Design Museum Holon
Pinkhas Eilon St 8
Holon 5845400

+972 73 2151525

www.dmh.org.il

content.title: The Tel Aviv Museum of Art: in perpetual growth

introduction.small: Established in 1932 in Mayor Meir Dizengoff's former villa, the museum constantly changed addresses, only to re-emerge in a new setting with deconstructivist traits in 2012.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Tel Aviv Museum of Art: in perpetual growth

paragraphs.text:
Israel's cultural capital is proud of the Herta and Paul Amir building that doubles the exhibition space of its art museum. Opened in autumn 2011, it is the work of American, Preston Scott Cohen, who appropriates modernism with deconstructivist traits.

Inside this modern, contemporary art museum there is, naturally, one of the world's largest collections of Israeli art in the fields of painting, sculpture, drawings and prints, photography, video, installations, architecture, and design. The classification of works is based on the chronology of the country: before the birth of the state, modern up to the 1970s, and contemporary.

Artists, patrons, and worldwide acquisition funds have enriched the permanent collections with works by Danziger, van Gogh, Chagall, Pissarro, Vlaminck, Kandinsky, Archipenko, Ernst, and Pollock… There is even a department dedicated to Old Masters of the 16th to the 19th century, including Brueghel the Younger and van Honthorst.

Tel Aviv Museum of Art
27 Shaul Hamelech Blvd
P.O. Box 33288
Tel Aviv

+972 03 6077020

www.tamuseum.org.il

content.title: Neve Tzedek: from pioneers to hipsters

introduction.small: Founded by Sephardic pioneers in 1887, the very touristy Neve Tzedek neighbourhood has become one of the trendiest places in Tel Aviv.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Neve Tzedek: from pioneers to hipsters

paragraphs.text:
Farewell to the eastern bohemian soul of the first Jewish neighbourhood built outside the walls of Jaffa in 1887 by Sephardic pioneers. Today it is a very trendy, gentrified area of Tel Aviv, with luxurious villas that contrast with the sandstone architecture of its original ochre houses.

Lively Neve Tzedek is full of cafés, restaurants, bars, and unique shops where you can find everything, including beautiful hand-made leather products. Stroll along Tayelet, the Mediterranean promenade, to get to the new port, full of funky cafés.

As for the historical former railway station, it has been transformed into a shopping and gastronomic centre that is worth visiting. Neve Tzedek was home to members of the Ashkenazi Jewish intelligentsia, like Samuel Joseph Agnon, the first Hebrew-language writer to win the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1966.

content.title: Jerusalem: 30 minutes by train

introduction.small: Thirty minutes now separate Jaffa from Jerusalem. It took four hours when the railway was built in 1892 about the same time it took for a carriage in 1869.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jerusalem: 30 minutes by train

paragraphs.text:
A fast train takes you from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem in half an hour. The holy city at the crossroads of cultures and religions, Jerusalem is, obviously, well worth a visit. The famous Dome of the Rock shows where Mohammed ascended to heaven, while the Church of the Holy Sepulchre marks, for Christians, the site of Golgotha, where Jesus was crucified.

The nearby Western Wall is one of the most sacred monuments of the Jewish religion. Stroll through the Garden of Gethsemane, populated by ancient olive trees, and then climb the Mount of Olives in the morning to discover stunning views of the city and the remains of the ancient City of David.

The Israel Museum has fascinating artefacts, including the famous Dead Sea Scrolls. Further afield, the Yad Vashem Holocaust History Museum offers a poignant and educational insight into one of the greatest tragedies of the 20th century.

www.yadvashem.org

content.title: The Carmel Market: a paradise for foodies

introduction.small: The Shuk Ha Carmel is the largest and best-known market in Tel Aviv. Walk it by going down its winding and very crowded streets towards the sea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Carmel Market: a paradise for foodies

paragraphs.text:
The bustling markets (in Hebrew ‘shuk') of Tel Aviv offer a glimpse of the great vitality of the city and its local products. The Carmel Market (Shuk Ha Carmel) on Carmel Street, near the fashionable neighbourhood of Neve Tzedek, is the largest and best known.

Enter it by Allenby Street and you immediately come upon fruit and vegetable stands displaying a fine range of local specialities. Do not miss the Borekas, puff pastry stuffed with cheese, spinach, or potatoes. This market is open every day, except on the Sabbath, Saturday, and is the best way to experience the local flavours in a relaxed and friendly atmosphere.

Stroll on to the sea on its adjacent, winding streets, where fish, meat, and clothing stands, as well as numerous restaurants, attract tourists and foodistas.

Carmel Market / Shuk HaCarmel
HaCarmel St 11
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 50 529 5668

content.title: Brown TLV Hotel

introduction.small: A stylish, charming, and contemporary boutique hotel in the arty Neve Tzedek neighbourhood. Savvy travellers drop their bags here first.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brown TLV Hotel

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by cafés, fashionable restaurants, and galleries, Brown TLV Hotel is a charming, contemporary address, renowned for its personalised service and warm and cosy interiors.

Housed in a former 1950s bank building, the hotel was restored by designer Rubi Israeli and architect Dario Grunzweig to recreate the glamorous atmosphere of the 1950s. The lounge on the ground floor, the true heart of the hotel, deploys vintage armchairs surrounded by libraries and contemporary art by local artist, Pilpeled. The 30 rooms feature custom-made furniture in smoky tones, a mix of modernity with 1950sfurniture.

Opt for the compact ‘Solo' or ‘Relax' rooms with Jacuzzi and balcony. Sit back in the Eames armchairs on the rooftop terrace or unwind in the outdoor baths, enjoying a 360-degree view of Tel Aviv's skyline.

Brown TLV Hotel
Kalischer Street 25
6516505 Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 7170200

www.brownhotels.com/tlv

Rooms: from 770 ILS

content.title: Jaffa: the bride of the sea

introduction.small: Like Acre, Jaffa more than 4,000 years old was one of the most important ports on the route to the Orient. Today it has become a historical and picturesque neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jaffa: the bride of the sea

paragraphs.text:
Many times looted and ransacked, the multi-millennial port of Jaffa is fascinating from all points of view. Its Oriental charm attracts history buffs, with sites ranging from the Clock Tower, built during the Ottoman era, to the Wishing Bridge on which you may read the signs of the zodiac represented as mosaics, and on from the old port one of the oldest in the world to its Shuk Hapishpeshim flea market.

Do not be surprised to spend hours discussing and negotiating with vendors when there buying jewellery, clothing, Persian mosaics, and curiosities of all kinds it's a real Aladdin's cave. Sunday morning, which opens the market week, is the perfect time to get there.

After a morning of palaver, treat yourself to a gourmet break in the Mediterranean breeze at one of the friendly cafés of the Old Port. You can then revisit the maze of picturesque alleyways in the city, dotted with the villas of American and Russian billionaires.

content.title: The Dan Tel Aviv rises on the waterfront

introduction.small: The first appeal of Dan Tel Aviv is its ideal location in the heart of the city, right on the waterfront. The second is its resolutely luxury approach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Dan Tel Aviv rises on the waterfront

paragraphs.text:
Exceptionally located on the seafront in the heart of Tel Aviv, the Dan hotel is impressive with its cascading rainbow-covered facade. The show continues with resolutely contemporary interiors, including 280 rooms facing the Mediterranean or revealing a unique view of the city.

Considered the first true luxury hotel in Tel Aviv, the Dan attracts politicians, businessmen, and artists, all in search of modern spaces near the beach and the centre. Indulge yourself with the Sea Executive Suites located on the top floors, offering stunning views of the Mediterranean.

To top it all off, the Dan also has two pools (with one on the roof), a fitness centre, spa, and restaurants. From the hotel, the Old Jaffa district is close by; you need only walk along the waterfront.

The Dan Tel Aviv
99 HaYarkon Street
Tel Aviv – Jaffa 63432

+972 03 5202525

www.danhotels.com

Rooms: from 1,220 ILS

content.title: To each their sandbox

introduction.small: From the popular beaches in the south to the more upscale in the north, the supply of sand is sufficient to accommodate spots for the religious, gays, surfers… and dogs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: To each their sandbox

paragraphs.text:
Tel Aviv's beaches stretch along the coast from Jaffa in the south to the Reading power station in the north. You can try different spots, starting with the lively Hof Metzitzim, then head up to the Hilton beaches and their waves, which appeal to surfers.

At the foot of the hotel, there is the gay beach, Atzmaut Beach, nicknamed ‘independence beach', adjoined by Nordau, the beach dedicated to the religious: Sunday, Tuesday, and Thursday it is reserved for women, the rest of the week for men, except Saturday, Shabbat, when the beach is public. Gordon and Frishman Beach follow below the French Embassy, where you'll hear a lot of French.

You can still continue further north, to the posh beaches of Tel Baruch and Mandarina, should you want to follow the beautiful people. Lastly, we should not forget to mention Hof Haklavim, which is open to dogs, man's best friend in Tel Aviv.

content.title: Abraxas North: out of the ordinary

introduction.small: The signature restaurant of Rothschild Boulevard, the Abraxas North does not like plates and constantly renews its menus.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Abraxas North: out of the ordinary

paragraphs.text:
Located just minutes from Rothschild Boulevard, the nerve centre of Tel Aviv's cultural scene, the Abraxas North brings a theatrical touch to the culinary scene of the city. The eccentric owner and chef Eyal Shani celebrates international flavours.

With a menu that changes daily according to the freshest ingredients available, he offers cutting-edge recipes and chats regularly with some of his customers sitting around his beautiful open kitchen. Expect flavours ranging from braised cabbage with grilled eggplant, through the European register (hamburger, crumbles). The restaurant's originality? The dishes are served on small paper plates, on cardboard, or in the pans used for cooking. We guess its because they don't like doing dishes here…

Intimate and unpretentious, the restaurant has high ceilings and hanging lamps that enhance the restaurant's charm. Head for the counter if you want to be served quickly.

Abraxas North
Lilienblum St 40
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 5166660

www.facebook.com/northabraxass/

Menu: around 85 ILS

content.title: The Artplus houses works of art

introduction.small: A chic and affordable hotel, decorated on each floor as a contemporary art gallery, in the centre of the Ben Yehuda neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Artplus houses works of art

paragraphs.text:
Ideally located in the heart of Ben Yehuda, between the beach and the Dizengoff Centre, the Artplus Hotel puts you next to the best restaurants and nightlife of Tel Aviv. This charming hotel doubles as a contemporary art gallery, with the aim of exposing the best of Israeli art. So the hotel management asked five famous local artists to decorate the five floors of the hotel according to their own style. Minimalist and compact, the 58 rooms unveil artwork painted on the walls. These include red drawings, scribbled by hand, from Elad Kopler in room 201 and the frescoes of Zadok Ben-David and Sigalit Landau along the corridors. Relax in the lobby's retro sofas facing the cutting-edge video projections, and, in fine weather, sunbathe on its very pleasant rooftop. A little bonus: the hotel offers you free entrance to Tel Aviv's new art museum.

Artplus Hotel Tel Aviv
Ben Yehuda St 35
Tel Aviv-Yafo

+972 03 7971700

www.atlas.co.il

Rooms: from 711 ILS

content.title: The Messa: a restaurant with a grand chef

introduction.small: The very trendy table of chef Aviv Moshe merges French, Mediterranean, and Eastern cuisine. Exceptional dishes in a glamorous setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Messa: a restaurant with a grand chef

paragraphs.text:
The Messa has white curtains, shiny marble floors, and grand wooden communal tables extending the full length of the room. Fascinating, complex, yet still comforting, the cuisine of chef Aviv Moshe's has revolutionised the restaurant scene in Tel Aviv with inventive, seasonal Mediterranean flavours. The recipes have a subtle balance of textures and tastes. Try the Thai salad served with wasabi sorbet, or the saffron risotto with figs, cashews and vegetable cheese. Cheese lovers will be delighted as there is a great choice of French ones. For dessert, choose between various sorbets, truly exceptional! If budget is a concern, you can enjoy Messa's gastronomy at a lower cost at lunchtime.

Messa
19 HaArba'a Street
Tel Aviv-Yafo 64739

+972 03 6856859

www.messa.co.il

Menu: around 238 ILS
